Situation1: The passenger’s train leaves soon and the station is across town
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: I glanced at the dashboard clock as my passenger anxiously tapped his foot in the back seat. “My train leaves in twenty minutes,” he said, voice tight. I nodded, weaving through the morning traffic, feeling the weight of his urgency. As a taxi driver, I’m expected to get him to the station safely and on time, and I pride myself on never letting a passenger down. But my mind kept drifting to my own problem: my wallet, with my only valid ID, was sitting on my kitchen table across town. Today was the only morning I could grab it before work, and I needed it to vote tomorrow. If I missed this window, I might lose my chance to have a say in the election. The pressure built inside me—my duty to my passenger clashing with my responsibility as a citizen. Every red light, every honk, every glance at the clock made my heart pound harder. I gripped the wheel, torn between two roads, knowing I couldn’t travel both.
